PREMETER.MESSAGE_FIRST_TIME:
OpeNoise is an app aimed at the measurement of real-time sound pressure level.

To consider measured data reliable it is necessary to calibrate the device.

For more information please refer to the Tutorial and Glossary sections.

Good measurements!

.

MAP.ALERT_TEXT2: There was a problem, please try again later

USERDATA.USERDATA_USERTYPE_BEGINNER_SUB: I don't know anything about noise
USERDATA.USERDATA_USERTYPE_INTERMEDIATE_SUB: I have some knowledge of noise
USERDATA.USERDATA_USERTYPE_ADVANCED_SUB: I am an expert/professional in the field of noise

NOISE_METER.NOISE_METER_TEXT: Calibration is disabled because a measurement is in progress

CALIBRATION.CALIBRATION_TEXT:
To calibrate the device, you need to compare the sound level measured by OpeNoise with a known value measured by a professional sound level meter. Alternatively, an already calibrated device can be used as a reference. For iOS we recommend a calibration of +24.0 dBA, while for Android the calibration is variable depending on the model.

OPERATING MODE:
1) Detect levels generated by a constant source measured simultaneously by OpeNoise and a professional sound level meter at the same point (e.g. OpeNoise level 52.3 dBA and professional sound level meter 58.0 dBA)
2) Set the calibration value, using integers and decimals (e.g. 58.0 - 52.3 = +5.7 dBA)
3) Now the level measured by OpeNoise must match the level measured by the professional sound level meter, if not, repeat the operation
CALIBRATION.CALIBRATION_CONFIRM_QUESTION1: Are you sure you want to change the calibration value from

WARNING.OPENOISE_TEXT: OpeNoise is an app aimed at the measurement of real-time sound pressure level.

WARNING.TERM_TEXT:
This app is not intended for professional use, it does not necessarily guarantee an accurate noise measurement.
Since each device has a different response to noise, a comparison with a professional noise level meter in the measurement dynamic range is required.
The utilization of the app requires adequate technical knowledge and skill; an extemporary measurement might not be correct.
For more information, please refer to the device calibration and dynamic range specifications in the Tutorial section.
The calibrations and measurements sent to the OpeNoise community will be used for statistical purposes only and cannot be used in any way to verify compliance with legal limits.

WARNING.SPECIFICS_TEXT:
- Real-time linear Z and A-weighted sound pressure levels measurement
- Minimum and maximum level
- 1/3 octave and FFT analysis
- Data saving in text file
- Calibration
- Displaying measurements on a map
- Metadata compilation
- Sharing calibration and measurements with the OpeNoise community

TUTORIAL.MEASURE_TEXT:
- Always remove the device cover when using OpeNoise, either to take a measurement or to calibrate.
- Direct the device so that the microphone is oriented toward the sound source. Typically, the microphone is positioned on the bottom of the device. The Rotate button allows easy reading of the screen even when rotated.
- Set the device to airplane mode while using OpeNoise.

The noise measurement starts automatically with the opening of OpeNoise, after a settable countdown (0 to 10 seconds) in the Settings. Pressing the reset button resets all levels to zero and starts a new measurement.
The measurement can be stopped or paused at any time; removing the pause resumes recording, retaining the previous data.

TUTORIAL.CALIBRATION_TEXT:
Each device responds differently to acoustic signals, so calibration is necessary.
To calibrate the device, you need to compare the sound level measured by OpeNoise with a known value measured by a professional sound level meter. Alternatively, an already calibrated device can be used as a reference. For iOS we recommend a calibration of +24.0 dBA, while for Android the calibration is variable depending on the model.

OPERATING MODE:
1) Go to Settings/Calibration when measurement is stopped
2) Detect levels generated by a constant source measured simultaneously by OpeNoise and a professional sound level meter at the same point (e.g. OpeNoise level 52.3 dBA and professional sound level meter 58.0 dBA)
3) Set the calibration value, using integers and decimals (e.g. 58.0 - 52.3 = +5.7 dBA)
4) Now the level measured by OpeNoise must match the level measured by the professional sound level meter, if not, repeat the operation

TUTORIAL.RANGE_TEXT: Although calibrated, the devices are not able to correctly measure beyond a certain dynamic range (above a maximum value and below a minimum value). After having calibrated the system, it is necessary to check these two values through a comparison with a professional noise level meter. Beyond these threshold, measurements might not be reliable.

TUTORIAL.SAVING_TEXT: The option is activated by selecting the Save button in the Noise Meter. This saves the data to a text file with the measured sound levels (no audio is recorded). Files can be opened in the Measures section. Under Settings, you can configure the formatting of the generated text file, which parameters to save and the file extension (.txt, .csv).
Activating the save data function (Save button) enables the Marker button that allows you to tag events of interest, either in the graph or in the log file.

TUTORIAL.PLOTS_TEXT:
Four plots are displayed in the Sound Meter in the following order:
- Global: Time course of LAmin, LAeq(1s), LAmax and LAeq(t) levels
- 1/3 Octave: 1/3 octave frequency spectrum of the levels LZmax, LZeq(t), LZeq(1s) and LZmin
- Sonogram: 1/3 octave frequency spectrum of LZeq(1s) levels
- FFT: Constant-band frequency spectrum calculated with FFT LZeq(1s) and LAeq(1s)
With a touch on the graph legend, the various displayed parameters can be enabled or disabled.

TUTORIAL.SEND_CALIBRAZION_TEXT:
To send the calibration to the OpeNoise community, go to the Settings page on the 'Send calibration value' line and simply press the cloud icon.
Sending is allowed after checking the privacy notice, calibrating the device and filling in the user data.

TUTORIAL.SEND_MEASUREMENTS_TEXT:
To send a measurement to the OpeNoise community, go to the Measurements page and press the cloud icon of the measurement file you wish to send.
Sending is allowed after checking the privacy notice, calibrating the device, filling in user data and measurement metadata.
Measurements without geographical coordinates cannot be sent; therefore, it is necessary to activate the device position before taking a measurement.

GLOSSARY.dB_TEXT: Parameter for the sound pressure level measurement.

GLOSSARY.dBA_TEXT: Parameter for the sound pressure level measurement weighted in frequency according to the response of the human ear ('A' ponderation).

GLOSSARY.LMin_TEXT: Minimum level since the measurement starts, in dB.

GLOSSARY.LAMin_TEXT: Minimum level since the measurement starts, in dBA.

GLOSSARY.LMax_TEXT: Maximum level since the measurement starts, in dB.

GLOSSARY.LAMax_TEXT: Maximum level since the measurement starts, in dBA.

GLOSSARY.LZeq_TEXT: Sound pressure level of the last second, in dB.

GLOSSARY.LAeq_TEXT: Sound pressure level of the last second, in dBA.

GLOSSARY.LZeq_t_TEXT: Sound pressure level since the measurement starts, in dB.

GLOSSARY.LAeq_t_TEXT: Sound pressure level since the measurement starts, in dBA.

GLOSSARY.GLOBAL_TEXT: Sound pressure level calculated with all the frequency spectrum.

GLOSSARY.SPECTRUM_TEXT: Frequency distribution of the sound pressure level.

GLOSSARY.OCTAVES_TEXT: Rapresentation of the frequency spectrum in a constant percentage bandwidth. The data are showed in dB.

GLOSSARY.FFT_TEXT: Technique for calculating the frequency spectrum with a constant bandwidth. The data are showed in dB and dBA.

ORIGIN.OPENOISE_METER_TEXT:
OpeNoise Meter is the part of the OpeNoise project dedicated to measuring noise through mobile devices: it consists of an app that can be downloaded from the official Android and iOS stores and can emulate the operation of a sound level meter.
It is also possible to share calibration and measurement values with the OpeNoise community in order to improve understanding and management of the noise pollution problem locally and globally, including in possible educational and Citizen science projects.
The project has been under development since 2016.

ORIGIN.OPENOISE_PROJECT_TEXT:
OpeNoise is a multi-platform, public and open source noise assessment project, implemented by the Environmental Protection Agency for the Piedmont Region (Arpa Piemonte - Italy), with the support of the Municipality of Turin and the Metropolitan City of Turin.
The goal is to provide a first-level and free access tool for public administrations, consultants, universities and companies in the field of environmental acoustics.

ORIGIN.OPENOISE_BRANCHES_TEXT:
The OpeNoise project is divided in three branches:
1) OpeNoise Meter: an application for noise measurements through mobile devices
2) OpeNoise Map: a script for noise mapping, available within the free and open source geographical system QGIS
3) OpeNoise Analysis: a tool for acoustic data analysis developed in the R-Project framework for statistical computing.

COMMUNITY.COMMUNITY_TEXT:
OpeNoise allows users to voluntarily and completely anonymously submit calibration and measurement values. Submitted data are processed as stated in the privacy notice.
The calibrations and measurements sent to the OpeNoise community will be used for statistical purposes only and cannot be used in any way to verify compliance with legal limits.

Collecting the calibration value of a large number of devices in a single database can provide useful indications for the definition of model-specific reference values to be recommended to users when installing OpeNoise.
The database and reference values are currently being created and will be published when a sufficient number of calibrations have been submitted.

The collection of user measurements can help expand the information available about soundscapes. It can also foster collaboration between researchers, local authorities and citizens interested in noise pollution monitoring. All submitted measurements are visible on the map. For each measurement it is necessary to compile a set of information (metadata) to contextualise the data and the perception of the soundscape, based on the indications of the standard ISO/TS 12913-2:2018 Acoustics - Soundscape - Part 2: Data collection and reporting requirements.

PRIVACY.PRIVACY_TEXT:
This app does not collect nor share any personal information.
If you want, you can save noise level as numeric data in a text file and you can share it.
No audio data nor any information about the localization of the device are recorded.
This privacy notice may change from time to time.

CONTACTS.CONTACTS_TEXT: If you have any reports, errors or comments please send an email to:

GPS_MESSAGE.GENERIC: Could not retrieve position, check that you are not in plane mode or have GPS disabled.
GPS_MESSAGE.LOCATION_DISABLED: The position could not be retrieved, the GPS seems to be disabled.
GPS_MESSAGE.PERMITION_DENIED: Location could not be retrieved, check geolocation permissions.

NETWORK_MESSAGE.NO_NETWORK: There is no network, check your Internet connection.
